'version': '2025-01-09-base', 'language': 'en', 'pageNumber': 0, 'inputText': 'LOCAL COLUMNIST February 4, 2024 at 12:00 a.m. by Richard Mason As I do my walk-run, which has become a lot more walk than run, I usually try to kill the boredom by thinking of what I could write about. Of course, a columnist must write an original column, which means no repeats. Well, I\'m somewhere north of 300 columns, and I\'ve covered a lot of ground both figuratively and metaphorically. The next part of being a good columnist is he or she must write something that is of interest to Arkansas readers. This past week, as I headed north toward Smackover, walking along the 167 Highway Bypass, one of the first flashes of interest was the amount of roadside trash. In my several years of walking-jogging, I\'ve spotted and sometimes picked up trash items, everything from a kitten to a Bible. By the way; the kitten was adopted, and it is doing well. Of course, most of the stuff along the side of the road was and is just trash. Beer and soft drink cans, Styrofoam cups, or whatever was in the back of pickup trucks whizzing along at 75 miles an hour make up most of the roadside trash, and from my traveling both foreign and domestic, I can confidently say Arkansas\'s roadway are in the top category when it comes to how much trash is there. Then, as I kept thinking of things to write about, it occurred to me that if we take a deeper look at the amount of trash not only along our roads, but in our downtowns, we are a nation of litterers. That\'s right, and if there is something we all have in common, it is that we litter. Although we might not throw beer cans out our truck\'s window, we are guilty of littering. Let me explain: Over the past couple of weeks with all the ice, sleet, and snow, most city trash trucks didn\'t run. Of course, a heavy frost will shut down a lot of schools and city services, but these past weeks were true work or study from home times. Was it climate change caused by global warming? You\'re damn right it was. "Yes, Virginia global warming is real!" The ice, snow, and cold records are a direct result of global warming. For some reason, the Arctic and Antarctic are heating faster than the rest of the planet, and that allows the Arctic and Antarctic Vortexes to break out and send out wave after wave of super fridge air. Now, back to the litter column. In a couple of days, trash built up to the point where city and private dumpsters were overflowing until a lot of trash was just thrown on the ground beside the dumpster. I was shocked at the amount of trash that was in the dumpsters or piled beside them from just a few days of no pickups. We, and that includes yours truly, are trashy people. I know you may say "So what? That trash is going to a land fill." Yes, most of it is, but that still makes it trash, and the tons upon tons of trash is just moved from one trash pile to another. Did it ever occur to you that global warming, which is causing climate change, is caused by the unnecessary use of energy it takes to produce those daily tons upon tons of trash? Or how much wasted energy it takes to incinerate the daily trash? 2023 was the hottest year on record, and 2024 looks on target to break that record, and the bottom line to this heating is wasted energy. That is how we litter in an indirect way. Let\'s say you purchase aspirins at the store. You take the little box home, open it up and take the aspirin bottle out. Then you toss the box and the cotton from the bottle in the trash. Right? Okay, now consider this and multiply it by a billion or so worldwide, and consider how much energy is just wasted and percolates carbon up into the atmosphere. We are a nation in a world of Wasted Energy People, and you and I litter every time we use one use items. It is obvious that unless there is a cataclysmic shift in attitude that we are going to continue that wasteful habit. Of course, our spineless legislature could pass laws prohibiting the commercial use of one-use items, in stores and food outlets. That would mean no plastic straws, or spoons, or Styrofoam cups, no plastic bags and all bottled drinks would be in returnable bottles. Oh, it will happen after searing summer heat of 130 degrees turns fall into summer and summer into hell. Unless we wake up and kick some legislature\'s collective butts, it is going to take living with Hell on Earth to start the ball rolling. We should treat every item we use as whether it is litter or non-litter. It can be done, but with the current shrug your shoulders and mutter, "Hot \'nough for ya?" response, our children and grandchildren and going to live in a Hell on Earth because we obviously don\'t give a ****. Of course, not only will they have to suffer through the heat, millions of climate refuges will flood the borders of more temperate countries, and the thousands we see fleeing from Central America to the United States will be replace by millions both in North America, but also in temperate Europe. But not only do we refuse to legislative any commonsense anti-littering laws, we don\'t enforce the ones we have. When I was on the Arkansas Department of Environmental Quality Commission, we pushed the Arkansas Highway Department to raise the fine for littering to $1000, and they did. Hundreds of litter report calls later, but not one fine of $1000 has been levied. Okay, I think I have made my point: we are a state in a nation full of litterers. You litter, I litter, and we all litter, but until that little fact sinks into our backwards brains, we are going to set record after record temperatures until probably our grandchildren are going to have to enact draconian laws to reverse global warming because the drastic climate changes portends to destroy our civilization as we know it. Email Richard Mason at [email protected]. Copyright © 2024, El Dorado News-Times All rights reserved. 'pageNumber': 0, 'inputText': 'February 5, 2024 at 12:00 a.m. by The Associated Press By JILL COLVIN Associated Press NEW YORK (AP) -- Former President Donald Trump offered a warning to the chair of the Republican National Committee Sunday morning, saying in an interview that, "they\'ll probably be some changes made." Trump had been asked by Fox News host Maria Bartiromo about Ronna McDaniel, who has been facing withering attacks from some Trump allies, including the group Turning Point, which was part of an unsuccessful effort to oust her last year. "I think she did great when she ran Michigan for me. I think she did OK, initially, in the RNC. I would say right now, they\'ll probably be some changes made," Trump said on FOX News Channel\'s Sunday Morning Futures. The RNC did not immediately respond to a request for comment. Trump was also pressed on the party\'s finances following campaign disclosures released this week that showed the RNC had just $8 million in the bank and $1 million in debt. "So I have a lot of money," Trump said in the interview that aired Sunday, arguing that "people are not looking at the RNC. They want changes." "You have to understand, I have nothing to do with the RNC. I\'m separate," he added. The comments come as Trump and his allies have been pushing the party to get behind him and effectively end the primary, even though he still faces a final major rival, his former U.N. Ambassador, Nikki Haley. McDaniel was criticized last month for saying Haley had no path to the nomination after Trump won the New Hampshire primary, telling Fox News: "We need to unite around our eventual nominee, which is going to be Donald Trump." An effort by Trump allies to have the RNC this week declare Trump the "presumptive nominee" was withdrawn after he came out against it. At the RNC\'s winter meeting in Las Vegas Friday, McDaniel, who won a fourth two-year term last year, called for the party to unite behind the goal of defeating President Joe Biden. "We Republicans will stick together, as united as the union our party long ago fought to preserve," McDaniel said, quoting Ronald Reagan, according to people who were in the room and disclosed her remarks on condition of anonymity to discuss a private gathering. While Trump and the RNC worked hand-in-hand on his losing 2020 bid, they have disagreed on a number of issues this time around. Trump refused to sign the party\'s loyalty pledge, skipped all of its sanctioned primary debates and has continued to cast suspicion on early and mail-in voting, even as the RNC pursues a "Bank Your Vote" initiative aimed at encouraging both. Trump, in the interview, also continued to push the party to rally behind him and at one point claimed Republican Senate Leader Mitch McConnell, who has been deeply critical of the former president since he left office, is interested in joining his growing list of endorsements. "I think Mitch McConnell wants to endorse me, that\'s what I hear," he alleged, adding. "Everybody\'s getting in line. They\'re all getting on board." Representatives for McConnell did not immediately respond to requests for comment. McConnell has made a point of staying out of the primary, but previously said he would support the eventual nominee.
